title: Parametric Functions - graph to meet conditions

content.prompt: The parametric function f is given by ft=xt,yt, where xt≤0 and yt≥0 for 0≤t≤2. Which of the following could be the graph of f ?

choices.label:
Neither axis has tick marks or a scale.

  • The curve begins at the origin with a point labeled t equals 0.
  • The curve decreases into the fourth quadrant to a point labeled t equals 1.
  • The curve continues to decrease, but less steeply, to reach the ending point labeled t equals 2.

assistive_label.label: Figure for Option A. Refer to its long description

choices.label:
Neither axis has tick marks or a scale.

  • The curve begins at the origin with a point labeled t equals 0.
  • The curve decreases from right to left, moving into the third quadrant to the point labeled t equals 1.
  • The curve continues to decrease from right to left, but less steeply, to reach the ending point labeled t equals 2.

assistive_label.label: Figure for Option B. Refer to its long description

choices.label:
Neither axis has tick marks or a scale.

  • The curve begins at the origin with a point labeled t equals 0.
  • The curve increases into the first quadrant to a point labeled t equals 1.
  • The curve continues to increase, but less steeply, to reach the ending point labeled t equals 2.

assistive_label.label: Figure for Option C. Refer to its long description

choices.label:
Neither axis has tick marks or a scale.

  • The curve begins at the origin with a point labeled t equals 0.
  • The curve increases from right to left, moving into the second quadrant to the point labeled t equals 1.
  • The curve continues to increase from right to left, but less steeply, to reach the ending point labeled t equals 2.

assistive_label.label: Figure for Option D. Refer to its long description

unit.text: 4: Functions Involving Parameters, Vectors, and Matrices (Not assessed on the AP Exam)

skill.text: Skill 2.B: Construct equivalent graphical, numerical, analytical, and verbal representations of functions that are useful in a given mathematical or applied context, with and without technology.
